unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked what's it *really* like in the Emergency Room, huh? Let me tell you, it's less "Grey's Anatomy" and more "chaos coordinated by caffeine." You'll see things you can't unsee, like the guy who thought he could deep-fry his samosas a little *too* enthusiastically, or the aunty who tripped over her own saree rushing to see a Bollywood star filming nearby. We had a case last week where someone came in complaining of a headache after watching too many episodes of Naagin. Dr. Sharma almost choked on his chai laughing.

unnormalised: Seriously though, it's a rollercoaster. One minute you're stitching up a kid who scraped his knee falling off his dad's Bajaj scooter, the next you're trying to figure out how Mr. Gupta managed to get a cricket ball stuck where the sun doesn't shine. Then, you're coding a patient who just had a heart attack on 14/02/2024 (Valentine's Day, of all days!). And yes, we *do* use those fancy medical terms you see on TV. Ever tried pronouncing "pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis" after being awake for 36 hrs straight? Good luck with that, buddy.

unnormalised: But jokes aside, it's incredibly rewarding. You get to make a real difference, even if it's just bandaging up a minor cut or telling someone that no, they don't need to rush to the ER because their naan is slightly burnt. It's about being there for people in their worst moments and, occasionally, laughing with them when they've done something incredibly silly. Just don't ask me what the ideal dosage of Crocin is at 3:00 AM – Google knows.
